,Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old male with severe COPD and a recent admission for COPD exacerbation. He is currently intubated and on ventilatory support in the ICU.

The patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of dyspnea and required intubation due to increased work of breathing. He has a history of dyspnea that improves only with an increase in steroid doses. His last spirometry showed Stage IV COPD with an FEV1 of 28% and FEV1/FVC of 55%. He did not improve with diuresis, nitro page, or nitro gtt, suggesting that this is not likely a CHF exacerbation. The patient also had a recent admission for COPD exacerbation and was treated with antibiotics for pseudomonas/MRSA+ sputum. However, he does have evidence of right lower lobe infiltrate on CT scan.

The plan includes obtaining a sputum sample if possible, following up with hospital sensitivities, continuing the current antibiotic regimen, and stress dose steroids. The patient is currently weaned successfully on CPAP 5/5 but still has increased work of breathing and is not ready for extubation yet. An increase in PEEP to 10 is being tried to aid his work of breathing.
The patient also has hyponatremia, which is believed to be hypovolemic hyponatremia due to poor oral"

I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
team for the key portions of the services provided. I agree with the
note above, including the assessment and plan. I would emphasize and
Mr [**Known lastname 5028**] remains intubated but more aware of his surroundings. He has
transitioned off 3% NS and is currently on CPAP and PSv of [**11-4**] cms
with continued use of accessory muscles. He has minimal secretions at
present through ETT and is not on pressors.
Exam notable for Tm of 99 BPof 152/71  HR of 95 RR of 16 with sats of
96% on FiO2 of 50% and 5 PEEP . he has diffuse expiratory wheezing with
distant breath and heart sounds. He has features of anasarca but more
so in his lower extremities ( till his thighs). Labs notable for WBC of
5.1 K, HCT of 31.1 , K+ of 4.6, Cr of 0.9 , Na of 126 ( 118) lactate of
1.5. CTA chest did now show occlusive pulmonary vascular disease but
did reveal RLL ASD and severe underlying COPD. EKG is without ischemic
Agree with plan to continue ventilatory support today with adjustment
of PSV/ CPAP settings and wean of FiO2. We will maximize
bronchodilators and continue with IV solumedrol and duonebs through
ETT. Broad antibiotics will also continue for now for suspected
nosocomial pathogens. Na has responded to 3% saline and now NS
infusion. It is likely a consequence of both appropriate (
hypoperfusion and hypovolemia) and inappropriate ADH release ( lung
disease). I have had a lengthy discussion with his family at the
bedside and they wish for continued ventilatory support and wish to
reverse DNR status. We will move towards attempts at extubation in next
24 hours if he responds to supportive Rx and normalizes metabolic
profile. Propafol appears to work well for sedation needs. He will need
a PICC line or A line today for phlebotomy purposes.
Remainder of plan as outlined above.

The patient has been on ventilatory support and is currently on CPAP/PSV with FiO2 of 50% and PEEP of 10 cmH2O. His blood gases show a pH of 7.47, PaCO2 of 28 mEq/L, and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 326. The patient's sodium levels are low at 126 mEq/L. He also has evidence of right lower lobe infiltrate on CT scan and a history of poor oral intake.

,Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old male with severe COPD and a recent admission for COPD exacerbation. He was admitted intubated after experiencing increased work of breathing (WOB) and hyponatremia. The patient's code status was changed to full code.

The patient has a history of dyspnea that improves only with an increase in his steroid doses. His last spirometry showed Stage IV COPD with an FEV1 of 28% and FEV1/FVC of 55%. He did not improve with diuresis, nitro page or nitro gtt, so this does not likely represent a CHF exacerbation. The patient also has evidence of right lower lobe infiltrate on CT scan.

The patient's sodium levels have been fluctuating between 126 and 128, indicating hyponatremia. He initially responded to IV fluids, suggesting hypovolemic hyponatremia. However, he has not fully corrected, and it is likely that he has a component of SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone secretion). The plan is to continue fluid restriction if urine lytes are consistent with SIADH and trend Na levels.
The patient's Hct has decreased from 31.1 to 27.7, indicating anemia. No clinical evidence of bleeding was found, and the Hct was 32.5 on admission."

The patient is a 66-year-old male with severe COPD and recent admission for COPD exacerbation. He is admitted intubated after experiencing increased work of breathing (WOB) and hyponatremia. The patient has a history of hypertension, angioedema, and allergies to Lisinopril and Mavik. He has been receiving various medications including heparin sodium, colace, prevacid, fe supp, wellbutrin, flovent, folate, insulin, verapamil, amlodipine, lasix, prednisone, atrovent, and lopressor.

24-hour events include hypertension yesterday with a blood pressure of 200s, for which the patient resumed his home medications. The patient has allergies to tetanus diphtheria, lisinopril, and trandolapril, and the last dose of antibiotics was piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn) at 01:23 AM and vancomycin at 08:46 AM.

Infusions include heparin sodium (prophylaxis) started at 12:02 AM. Other ICU medications are also being administered. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for increased WOB and hyponatremia.

Flowsheet data shows the patient's vital signs, hemodynamic monitoring, fluid balance, respiratory support, and oxygen delivery device. The patient's blood gases indicate an ABG of ///34. Physical examination findings include extremities with +3+ edema, and the peripheral vascular examination was not assessed. Neurologic examination was also not assessed.

Laboratory results show elevated levels of white blood cells (WBC), hemoglobin (Hct), and platelets (Plt). Kidney function tests reveal increased creatinine (Cr) levels. Glucose levels have been fluctuating, and other lab results including PT/PTT/INR, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T, differential leukocyte count, albumin, calcium, magnesium, and phosphate levels are within normal range. Imaging and microbiology results indicate the presence of Pseudomonas and MRSA colonization.

Assessment and plan include respiratory failure due to severe COPD, possibly exacerbated by pneumonia or aspiration. Antibiotics vancomycin and Zosyn have been initiated, pending culture sensitivity profile. Prednisone taper has been prescribed, and a follow-up CT scan in 6 weeks is recommended to ensure pneumonia resolution. Contact with an outpatient pulmonologist has been made.

Other medical issues include hypertension, which requires optimization of verapamil and amlodipine, and hypokalemia, which has resolved. Anemia is stable, and the patient's ICU care includes nutrition support, glycemic control, and prophylactic measures for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, nosocomial infections such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSI), further electrolyte imbalances, and possible progression of kidney dysfunction."
